sn7.10:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn7.10:1.2: Now at that time one of the brahmins of the Bhāradvāja clan had lost fourteen oxen.
sn7.10:1.3: While looking for them he went to that forest, where he saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged, with his body straight, and mindfulness established right there.
sn7.10:1.4: He went up to the Buddha, and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn7.10:16.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin said to the Buddha,
sn7.10:16.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn7.10:16.4: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn7.10:16.5: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
sn7.10:17.1: And the brahmin received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
sn7.10:17.2: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
sn7.10:17.3: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
sn7.10:17.4: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.
